Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation2: The task sits on the critical path for an external delivery promised to a client.
Story: I walked beside my younger brother, our backpacks bouncing in rhythm as we made our way down Maple Street. Mom always reminded me to keep an eye on him, especially after that time he tripped near the busy intersection. Today, though, my mind kept drifting to the urgent emails piling up on my phone. The project at work was at a standstill until I finished my part, and the client was already getting impatient. My manager had sent a reminder: “We need your update by 5 PM sharp.” I glanced at the time—4:15. We still had a good twenty minutes left to walk, and my brother was chattering about his day, oblivious to my growing anxiety. I knew I could let him walk the last few blocks alone; he was old enough, and it would give me just enough time to get home and finish the task. But what if something happened? I felt torn, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides, my brother’s safety on one hand and my team’s trust on the other. My heart pounded as I tried to decide what to do next.
